DEATH OF MEMBER


Announcement by Mr Speaker


    Mr Speaker: It was with profound shock and deep sorrow that I, and, I am sure, Honourable Members heard the news of the death of the Honourable Member for Anson, Inche Baharuddin bin Mohamed Ariff, on Thursday, 20th April, 1961. In accordance with the Law, I have duly acquainted His Excellency the Yang di-Pertuan Negara of the resultant vacancy in this Assembly.

    I desire, on behalf of the House, to record with regret an expression of our sense of the loss we have sustained and our deep sympathy for the family of the Member.

Column: 1403

OBITUARY SPEECHES



    The Deputy Prime Minister (Dr Toh Chin Chye): Mr Speaker, no one can speak of sorrow unless he has felt the anguish of sorrow. No one can write of pain unless he has suffered the pangs of pain. And if those in sorrow and pain ask us for the answer to the eternal question of life and death, who can blame us if we can give no answer? We can only give consolation. And if an epitaph were to be written, I can find no better phrase than this simple verse from the Rubaiyat:

    `Then said another, "Surely not in vain

    My substance from the common earth was taken

    That he who subtly wrought me into shape

    Should send me back to common earth again."'

    Sir, if we lived in an age of despair, then little else could be said. But today we live in an age of faith and hope, faith

Column: 1404

in ourselves and hope for the future of the Malayan nation and our country. And it is with faith and hope that the late Member for Anson, Inche Baharuddin, came forward to take part in the leadership of the country.

    He sacrificed security in his old position as a journalist in the Utusan Melayu to face insecurity as a leader of the people. Inche Baharuddin had served the people in the City Council and in the Legislative Assembly. He was rare as a leader. He was broadminded and tolerant in accordance with the tenets of his Islamic faith. He was loyal to the people whom he represented, and on the very evening of his death he was with them in Anson listening to their complaints and trying to find an answer to their questions.

    Sir, I speak not as a partisan, not because Inche Baharuddin was a member of the P.A.P., but I speak in respect of his virtues and qualities as a leader among the people, as a representative of the people who had sat among us in this Chamber. There was so much to hope in a man so young, and can you blame us if we are bitter that that hope is knocked out without any warning?

    The people today have a great need for leaders who are prepared to be self-sacrificing. If we hope to build our budding nation, if we hope to succeed in our quest for building our united Malayan nation, then it is absolutely necessary that leaders from all communities must work together to achieve this purpose. Inche Baharuddin, young as he was, had the faith that a Malayan nation could be built. He had the hope, although he did not live to see his faith and hope fulfilled, that the time will come when we will all be marching from strength to strength in our task of nation-building.

    Mr Speaker, you have been in this Chamber for the last six years. You have witnessed stormy scenes. You have heard words flung across the Floor of this Chamber in anger, in bitterness, in acrimony. But, Sir, all anger, all bitterness, all pain, are finally dissolved in death.

Column: 1405



    Tun Lim Yew Hock (Cairnhill): Mr Speaker, Sir, those whom the gods love die young. And so we lost a very good friend, Inche Baharuddin, who was taken away much too young. He had many years of service before him, and therefore his death is indeed a loss to all of us and to the country.

    I would like to associate myself with all the words of sorrow expressed by the Leader of the House. But I would just like to add one little bit - to say that the loss which has been suffered by his family and by the country is also a personal loss to me, because he has been a very good and personal friend of mine.

    Mr Speaker: As a mark of respect to the late Member, I propose to suspend this sitting. I shall take this Chair again at ten minutes to three.

ECONOMIC ASSISTANCE TO MALAY CITIZENS OF SINGAPORE


    2. Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi asked the Minister for Finance whether the Government has any plans for giving economic assistance to the Malay citizens of Singapore.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, before I go into the details of what the Government is now doing and what it intends to do to assist Singapore Malays, I wish to outline some of the principal features of the economic position of the Malays in Singapore.

    Any plan for economic assistance must be based on a correct appraisal of the present situation and present needs. The 1957 census gives us some indications. Unfortunately, the census figures do not distinguish between Malays and Indonesians in the statistics on occupation. But this is only a minor disadvantage as the broad picture is clear enough.

    In 1957 there were 57,300 Malays and Indonesians working. There were 3,800 stated to be unemployed. Of the 57,300 persons working, a great majority worked as employees. The number of employees amounted to 51,400. These are the people who work for a wage or a salary. There were also, in addition, some 5,900 who were self-employed, and most of these are fishermen, hawkers and such like.

    The first feature about the economic status of the Malays in Singapore is that a great majority of them are paid employees. In this regard, the Malays in Singapore differ fundamentally from the Malays in the Federation where a great

Column: 1407

majority are not employees but are farmers and fishermen - people who work on their own account.

    Further, of the 51,400 employees, no less than 26,900 are employed by the Government, statutory corporations, the City Council and the British Defence Departments. Some 11,300 work for the Government and the City Council, and some 11,800 work for the British Defence Departments. From this fact, it therefore follows that employment opportunities in the public service are matters of great importance to the Malay citizens in Singapore. More detailed and up-to-date figures in respect of Central Government monthly-rated employees are available. On 31st December, 1959, of 22,966 employees in the Central Government, no less than 6,908 are Malays.

    As regards the general standard of living of the Malay population, not much by way of a scientific study has been made, although this does not prevent people from hazarding all kinds of loose generalisations. When I was a civil servant, I carried out a study of incomes in Singapore among the urban working-class population. In 1953/54, I conducted an extensive social survey in the City of Singapore to find out the conditions of those families depending on earners whose incomes do not exceed $400 per month each. Some 83 per cent of Singapore families living in the city fall within this income bracket. Within the survey group which, by and large, represents what we may loosely term the working class, the average income of a Malay family compares well with the others. Malay families earn an average of $160 per month as against $148 of the general average. Within this selected group, that is to say, among working-class families, it can be said that the notion that Malays are worse off than others does not hold true. But this proposition cannot be generalised over the whole strata of society. If we include all persons - rich, the well-to-do, and the poor together - we find that the proportion of Malays whose incomes are high enough to exclude them from the survey is a small

Column: 1408

one. Only 6 per cent of Malay families have earners receiving an income of $400 a month or more as against the general average of 17 per cent. This means that in the urban Malay society the number of middle-class persons with professional occupations is much smaller than the general average of all communities. It is likely that if the people in the rural areas are included, the picture will not be much different. It is against this background that we have to consider what action can be taken to maintain and improve the economic welfare of the Malays. The first must be that employment opportunities for Malays in the Government service and in statutory authorities generally should be maintained, and this is vital since more than half of the Malay population are depending on their livelihood on this occupation-

    The Chairman: Will the Minister signify the recommendation of the Yang di-Pertuan Negara before the Committee proceeds with the consideration of these Supplementary Estimates?

    The Minister for Finance (Dr Goh Keng Swee): I so signify.

    The Chairman: First Supplementary Estimates of Expenditure for 1961 (Paper Cmd. 13 of 1961). The summary is at page 6.

    There is an amendment on Head 36, Inland Revenue, at page 2, standing in the name of the Member for Kampong

Kembangan in relation to the New sub-head - Temporary Staff. Inche Mohd. Ali.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 36 be reduced by $10 in respect of the new sub-head (Temporary Staff).

    Mr Speaker, in my opinion, the amount of $66,000 allocated for Temporary Staff should not be limited to that sum alone. What has become a question mark to me is why that amount is voted for Temporary Staff in order to take charge of a new department in the interests of the State of Singapore. Would it not be better if permanent staff were recruited, and not initially temporary? If permanent staff were recruited, it would be made through the Public Service Commission and then there would be no doubt in the minds of the Opposition Members. If, on the other hand, temporary staff were to be engaged - I do not know whether the Minister concerned could enlighten us as to the reason why - would the temporary staff be drawn from members of the Work Brigade or from such members as were favourably considered by the Government?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the underlying note of the two remarks of the Member for Kampong Kembangan is that somebody is going to do a fiddle over temporary staff. He thought that a far better arrangement would be to get this new department staffed by permanent officers so that their appointments could be decided by the Public Service Commission, thereby giving no room for any possibility of fiddling appointments. Now, the Member is under a misapprehension. It is not true that only permanent appointments are decided by the Public Service Commission. Any appointment, temporary or otherwise, for a period of two months or more must be approved by the Public Service Commission. The Public Service Commission Ordinance is explicit on that score and, in fact, this is the practice which the Government is observing.

Column: 1410



    I can assure the Member that the reason why we are recruiting temporary staff is not that we have any intention to fiddle appointments - that is not the way the P.A.P. Government conducts its business - but there is a more simple explanation and it is this. The operation of registering businesses will probably begin sometime about the middle of the year. The Bill introducing the Business Registration Tax will be passed in the Assembly before long, but until that Bill is passed, no work can start. Therefore, in the first year of operation, this new department will have about six months or less to do a whole year's work. It is therefore necessary to engage people temporarily to tide over this rush. That is the reason why we have decided to ask the Assembly for this vote to enable us to engage more staff on a temporary basis than would be required on a long-term basis by this department.

    Mr A. P. Rajah (Farrer Park): Mr Speaker, Sir, I understood the Minister to say that this staff would be required to register businesses in order to extract tax. As I appreciate the situation, there is already an organisation whereby all persons carrying on businesses in Singapore are required to register under the Business Registration Ordinance. If that is so, what then is the need to employ all this temporary staff to effect that registration, because the registration should already have been effected?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the present Business Registration Ordinance provides for a once and for all registration. Once you register, that is the end. That department has no more work to do as far as relations with that firm are concerned. But in this case, it is a different matter. You have to keep in touch with them year by year. Every year, you have to inform the Registry that they are in existence and that they should pay their tax. Therefore, the volume of work will be much larger than the work handled by the present Registry of Business Names.

Column: 1411



    Mr Thio Chan Bee (Tanglin): Mr Speaker, Sir, as there are thousands of unemployed, I am sure a good many would be disappointed and frustrated unless they know in advance on what basis the selection for this temporary staff will be made. Could we be enlightened, Sir?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Mr Speaker, Sir, the number of staff we intend to engage is as follows:

    Clerks ... 20

    Typists ... 8

    Office Boy ... 1

    I do not think that that is going to raise much hope in the thousands and thousands of unemployed.

    Mr Rajah: Perhaps, Sir, we are now involved in the mechanics of tax collection. Now, as I understand it, there is a Business Names Ordinance - this Ordinance has been in force since 1940 - under which anyone who carries on a business in Singapore must register. Having registered, he must also notify the Registrar of Business Names of the change in partners and that sort of thing. So there is in existence now a skeleton staff anyway which knows who are the persons carrying on a business, what are the businesses registered, and where they are situated. Having reached that point, the next point I take it will be to extract tax from these businesses every year. Now, I do not know what the new Ordinance is going to say, Mr Speaker, Sir, but it seems to me that possibly a lot of money could be saved if extensive powers were given to the Registrar of Business Names to collect the tax every year, rather than give it to some specially created revenue collecting department.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Yes, Sir, that is exactly what we intend to do. The present Registry will be the nucleus of this new department. It was formerly in the Ministry of Labour and Law, and when we contemplated introducing this tax, it has since been removed to my Ministry.

Column: 1412



    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, to revert to the answer given by the Minister for Finance, I appreciate the explanation given that there will be no fiddling with the appointments, but what still remains a question mark to me is whether it is true or otherwise. I know that in the Work Brigade there are members who have passed the School Certificate examination with Grade II or Grade III. Will there be the possibility that those who are not members of the Work Brigade but who have higher qualifications can be absorbed into this temporary staff? I would like to know what are the qualifications required of applicants for these temporary staff posts. Are the qualifications required on the same basis as that who are unemployed now?

    Mr Rajah: Sir, I think the doubt in the mind of the Member for Kampong Kembangan arises from a statement made by the Minister for Labour and Law some time ago to this Assembly, when he said that instructions had been given by his Ministry that, in so far as the filling of any future Government appointments was concerned, the first choice should be given to members of the Work Brigade. I believe that is what is at the back of the mind of the Member for Kampong Kembangan.

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: Let me dispose of the statement about recruitment from the Work Brigade. The present position is that for certain types of jobs in the Government service - they are jobs in the daily-rated services, Division IV appointments, which are not promotion posts - recruitment for these appointments are made from members of the Work Brigade. We have also come to an arrangement with several statutory authorities, including the Singapore Harbour Board, whereby they will recruit from the Work Brigade for similar posts. We have also had requests for assistance in recruiting workers from firms, manufacturers and others who want good workers. We have made use of Work Brigade members, suitably qualified and trained, for recommendation to such posts. Now the temporary

Column: 1413

posts relevant to this exercise are not the posts for which we make special arrangements to select from the Work Brigade. Clerical officers are in Division III. Typists are in Division IV. They are regarded as promotion posts for more junior staff. We may recruit the office boy, but that is only one.

3.15 p.m.

    As regards the qualifications for temporary staff, the qualifications laid down will not have any relation to how the unemployed are qualified, but they must be related to the work and responsibilities which these people have to perform. For instance, for clerical officers, the minimum educational qualification will be the Senior Cambridge or the equivalent academic standard. For typists, it will be somewhat lower, and for the office boy, it will be still lower. The qualifications laid down will be the same in comparable jobs in the Government service.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I have another question to ask. Will this opportunity be only limited to citizens of Singapore in view of the fact that they are temporary posts? Or will it be open to all and sundry?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: The posts in Divisions III and IV will be limited to Singapore citizens.

    Mr Rajah: I think a further point arises in the selection of Divisions III and IV posts. In view of the circular that has been issued by the Minister for Labour and Law, is it going to be an advantage to be a member of the Work Brigade in order to get an appointment in this department if the posts are in Divisions III and IV? I understand that Division III is outside it. What this House wants to know is this. Insofar as Division IV appointments are concerned, covered by this temporary staff, would it be an advantage to be a member of the Work Brigade? Or is it compulsory that he should be a member of the Work Brigade? Or is it open to all?

    Dr Goh Keng Swee: So far, as the office boy is concerned, he will be recruited from the Work Brigade.

    Head 47 -

    The Chairman: There are four notices of amendments standing in the name of the Member for Kampong Kembangan. The first is in relation to "New item - Assistant Head ... $7,700" on page 2.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move,

    That the sum to be allocated for Head 47 be reduced by $10 in respect of the new item (Assistant Head).

    Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like to receive clarification from the Minister for Culture on more or less the same question as I have asked the Minister for Finance. Will the prospective Assistant Head carry out the policies already formulated by the Head of the Department who has been made available to us from Indonesia? According to my interpretation, the appointment of an Assistant Head will mean that the Ministry will be short of staff, and that it will only begin to operate. If the contrary is the case - plans might have been formulated but there is no staff - could the Minister for Culture explain to me the position?

    The Minister for Culture (Mr S. Rajaratnam): Mr Speaker, Sir, I am not quite clear about the question. I gather the question is whether the Assistant Head would carry out the policies laid down by the present Head of the Dewan. Of course, the Assistant Head's function would be to assist the Head in administering the Dewan. To that extent, he would have to carry out the broad policies laid down by the Head of the Dewan who, in turn, discusses with the Minister the general policy of the Dewan.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, Sir, I would like further enlightenment from the Minister for Culture. The staff is for the Dewan Bahasa dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan. Will the Assistant Head be a Malay? If that is so, will he be selected from among persons with diplomas, such as a B.A. from

Column: 1415

the University of Malaya? Or will the Government engage au Assistant Head from among persons with qualifications and experience and who are now employed in the Malay section of Radio Singapore?

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, this Government does not make appointments in terms of whether a person is a Malay, a Chinese or an Indian. We advertise in terms of particular skills and abilities required for a post, and the person most suited would naturally be selected by the Public Service Commission. In this case, this post has already been advertised - I think it was on Monday - and the qualifications and experience necessary are an Honours degree of a recognised University plus experience in writing and post-graduate research, preferably academic research, in an institution of higher learning, administrative ability and leadership. So it will be left to the P.S.C. to decide from among the applicants the person who would be most suited to fill the post.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker. Sir, I am aware of the explanation given by the Minister for Culture. As he is from a Socialist Party - subject to correction - it may be that the P.A.P. is always right in implementing its policies. But could the P.S.C. engage only a Malay? It is not our responsibility but it is the responsibility of the P.S.C. But if the Government could so direct, I believe the opportunity could be given to the Malays because only one man is required. The responsibilities of this post, to carry out the functions and operations of the Dewan Bahasa dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan, are great. If, however, the Assistant Head is a non-Malay - I am not suggesting the Government policy cannot be implemented - I think it is proper that the Government should look to the Federation. I am not going to teach the Government, but the staff of the Dewan Bahasa should comprise more Malays who will be the pioneers to implement the Government policy. This is my opinion, Mr Speaker.

Column: 1416



    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, the functions of the Dewan are well known to Members of the Assembly. There are two functions. One is to foster the development and the popularisation of the national language, which is Malay; and the second is to undertake research in connection with the primary aim of integrating the various cultures and of spreading a knowledge of those cultures. So it is inevitable that whoever is the Head of the Dewan shoud be one who is most capable of discharging these functions. It will therefore depend on who can best discharge those functions. He may be a Malay or anybody else, so long as we choose the right person who can discharge these two essential functions - one, to spread knowledge of the national language (Malay), and to help in the research and development of the language; and two, to carry out sociological duties in connection with cultural work. The staff has been chosen with the view that, apart from the Malay language, the other three languages and the four cultures are involved. It is impossible to find one man who can carry out this work and therefore the staff must be balanced in such a way that they can complement one another's work.

3.30 p.m.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, in any case that is the Government's responsibility. I have duly conveyed my views.

    Another point, Mr Speaker. Can I be informed whether administrative correspondence in this Dewan will be in Malay, the national language? I ask because I know that the status of the national language has not yet been made official, and I would like to know whether the national language will be used in the daily administration of the Dewan.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, the use of the national language in this Dewan will depend on the extent to which use would be made of the national language in the whole administration. But here again, in view of the present transitional phase of our development, it would obviously be impractical to send, say, a

Column: 1417

letter in Malay to a Chinese cultural organisation which might have individuals who do not understand the national language. So the use of the particular language will depend on to whom correspondence is being sent. It is no use sending a letter in English to somebody who knows only Malay, and it is no use sending a letter in Malay to somebody who knows only Chinese. It is hoped that as we go on and as the national language is extensively used throughout the administration, the Dewan too will make better use of the national language.

    Inche Mohd. Ali Bin Alwi(In Malay): Mr Speaker, I move,

    Mr Speaker, the subject of culture has been discussed at previous sittings of the Assembly. We are in the dark as to which culture we should adopt - whether it is Government culture, or culture as understood by Members of the Opposition. In short, there may be one, two, three, or four cultures. I hope the Minister for Culture will explain to us what is culture, so that we could consider his views and remarks.

    Mr Rajaratnam: Mr Speaker, Sir, I am delighted at the capacity for punishment that Members of the Opposition show in not only being prepared to listen to a lecture on culture, but also inviting the Minister for Culture at this late juncture to deliver a long lecture on culture which I am always prepared to do. In view of the fact that we are going to spend a large sum of money in establishing a Dewan Bahasa dan Kebudayaan Kebangsaan, I hope the Member for Kampong Kembangan will be able to satisfy his curiosity about culture in general by not only attending the lectures and activities which are organised by the Dewan but also by perusing the excellent publications which will be produced by the Research Officers of whose functions he was not quite well aware.

    Tun Lim Yew Hock: Sir, the Opposition is not curious.
